intro: Rosa cuspidatoides var. pseudocuspidata, commonly known as the narrow-leaved rose, is a deciduous shrub native to the eastern United States. It features slender, arching stems with thorny branches and small, elliptical leaves that are typically 2–4 inches long. The plant produces fragrant, single or semi-double flowers in shades of pink to white, usually blooming in late spring to early summer. Its foliage turns vibrant red in the fall, adding ornamental value throughout the growing season. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and is relatively low maintenance, making it a popular choice for gardeners.
